user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueDelete:
```c
int32 OS_QueueDelete(osal_id_t queue_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_QueueDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_QueueDelete_Impl(&token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Cannot determine from this call alone. The fragment only shows a pointer being passed (&token); Rule 8.13 is concerned with the declaration of the pointer parameter. A violation would occur if OS_QueueDelete_Impl is declared to take OS_object_token_t * (non-const) but does not modify the object — in that case the parameter should be declared const OS_object_token_t * and the call should pass &token. If OS_QueueDelete_Impl is declared to take a pointer-to-const or actually modifies the token, then there is no violation.
